The `getminingdistribution` command retrieves the current mining distribution. It does not accept any arguments and returns a NULL object if the mining distribution is not set, or a JSON object with destination addresses and their relative values if it is set.

Examples:
```bash
> verus getlocalsolps
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "getlocalsolps", "params": [] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `getminingdistribution`
Retrieves current mining distribution#### Arguments
NONE#### Result:
```
NULL object if not set
If set:
{
 "uniquedestination1":value  (key/number) valid destination address and relative value output to it
 "uniquedestination2":value  (key/number) destination address and relative value output
 ...
}
```#### Examples:
```bash
> verus getminingdistribution
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "getminingdistribution", "params": [] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```
What is the purpose of the `getlocalsolps` command?

The purpose of the `getlocalsolps` command is not specified. However, based on the examples, it appears to be a command that retrieves some kind of information, possibly related to local solo proof-of-stake (SOLPS) settings.

Examples:
```bash
> verus getlocalsolps
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "getlocalsolps", "params": [] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `getminingdistribution`
Retrieves current mining distribution#### Arguments
NONE#### Result:
```
NULL object if not set
If set:
{
 "uniquedestination1":value  (key/number) valid destination address and relative value output to it
 "uniquedestination2":value  (key/number) destination address and relative value output
 ...
}
```#### Examples:
```bash
> verus getminingdistribution
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "getminingdistribution", "params": [] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```
Can I use the `getminingdistribution` command to retrieve the mining distribution of a remote node?

No, the `getminingdistribution` command retrieves the current mining distribution of the local node. It does not retrieve the mining distribution of a remote node. The examples provided show how to use the command locally, or by making a JSON-RPC request to the local node using `curl`.

Examples:
```bash
> verus getlocalsolps
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "getlocalsolps", "params": [] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `getminingdistribution`
Retrieves current mining distribution#### Arguments
NONE#### Result:
```
NULL object if not set
If set:
{
 "uniquedestination1":value  (key/number) valid destination address and relative value output to it
 "uniquedestination2":value  (key/number) destination address and relative value output
 ...

```#### Examples:
